Whither is Europe's ancient spirit fled?</br>Where are those valiant tenants of her shore,</br>Who from the warrior bow the strong dart sped,</br>Or with firm hand the rapid pole-axe bore?</br>Freeman and soldier was their common name.</br>Who late with reapers to the furrow came,</br>Now in the front of battle charg'd the foe:</br>Who taught the steer the wintry plough t' indure,</br>Now in full councils check'd incroaching pow'r,</br>And gave the gen'ral weal its majesty to know.

But who are ye?  from Ebro's loit'ring sons</br>To Tiber's pageants, to the sports of Seine;</br>From Rhine's frail palaces to Danube's thrones</br>And cities bord'ring on the Cimbric main,</br>Ye lost, ye self-deserted?  whose proud lords</br>Have baffled your tame hands, and giv'n your swords</br>To slavish ruffians hir'd for their command:</br>These, at some greedy monk's or harlot's nod,</br>See rifled nations crouch beneath their rod:</br>These are the public will, the reason of the land.

Thou, heedless Albion, what, alas!  the while</br>Dost thou presume?  O inexpert in arms,</br>Yet vain of freedom, how cost thou beguile</br>With dreams of hope these near and loud alarms?</br>Thy splendid home, thy plan of laws renown'd,</br>The praise and envy of the nations round,</br>What care hast thou to guard from fortune's sway?</br>Amid the storms of war, how soon may all</br>The lofty pile from its foundations fall,</br>Of ages the proud toil, the ruin of a day!

No:  thou art rich.  thy streams and fertile vales</br>Add industry's wise gifts to nature's store:</br>And every port is crouded with thy sails,</br>And every wave throws treasure on thy shore.</br>What boots it?  If luxurious plenty charm</br>Thy selfish heart from glory, if thy arm</br>Shrink at the frowns of danger and of pain,</br>Those gifts, that treasure is no longer thine.</br>A coward's golden heaps malignant shine</br>Bribing rapacious force to work their owner's bane.

But what hath force or war to do with thee?</br>Girt by the azure tide and thron'd sublime</br>Amid thy floating bulwarks, thou canst see,</br>With scorn the fury of each hostile clime</br>Dash'd ere it reach thee.  Sacred from the foe</br>Are thy fair fields.  athwart thy guardian prow</br>No bold invader's foot shall tempt the strand—</br>Yet say, my country, will the waves and wind</br>Obey thee?  Hast thou all thy hopes resign'd</br>To the sky's fickle faith?  the pilot's wavering hand?

For O!  may neither fear nor stronger love</br>(Love, by thy virtuous princes nobly won)</br>Thee, last of many wretched nations, move,</br>With mighty armies station'd round the throne</br>To trust thy safety.  Then, farewell the claims</br>Of freedom!  Her proud records to the flames</br>Then bear, an off'ring at ambition's shrine;</br>Whate'er thy ancient patriots dar'd demand</br>From fierce Plantagenet's or Stuart's hand,</br>Or what great William seal'd for his adopted line.

But if thy sons be worthy of their name,</br>If lib'ral laws with lib'ral hearts they prize,</br>Let them from conquest, and from servile shame</br>In war's glad school their own protectors rise.</br>Ye chiefly, heirs of Albion's cultur'd plains,</br>Ye leaders of her bold and faithful swains,</br>Now not unequal to your birth be found:</br>The public voice bids arm your rural state,</br>Paternal hamlets for your ensigns wait,</br>And grange and fold prepare to pour their youth around.

Why are ye tardy?  what inglorious care</br>Detains you from their head, your native post?</br>Who most their country's fame and fortune share,</br>'Tis theirs to share her toils, her perils most.</br>Each man his task in social life sustains.</br>With partial labours, with domestic gains</br>Let others dwell:  to you indulgent heav'n</br>By counsel and by arms the public cause</br>To serve for public love and love's applause,</br>The first imployment far, the noblest hire, hath given.

Have ye not heard of Lacedaemon's fame?</br>Of Attic chiefs in freedom's war divine?</br>Of Rome's dread gen'rals?  the Valerian name?</br>The Fabian sons?  the Scipios, matchless line?</br>Your lot was theirs.  the farmer and the swain</br>Met his lov'd patron's summons from the plain;</br>The legions gather'd; the bright eagles flew:</br>Barbarian monarchs in the triumph mourn'd;</br>The conqu'rors to their household gods return'd,</br>And fed Calabrian flocks, and steer'd the Sabine plough.

Shall then this glory of the antique age,</br>This pride of men, be lost among mankind?</br>Shall war's heroic arts no more ingage</br>The unbought hand, the unsubjected mind?</br>Doth valour to the race no more belong?</br>No more with scorn of violence and wrong</br>Doth forming Nature now her sons inspire,</br>That, like some mystery to few reveal'd,</br>The skill of arms implicitly they yield,</br>And from their own defence abash'd and aw'd retire?

O shame to human life, to human laws!</br>The loose advent'rer, hireling of a day,</br>Who his fell sword without affection draws,</br>Whose God, whose country, is a tyrant's pay,</br>This man the lessons of the field can learn;</br>Can every palm, which decks a warrior, earn,</br>And every pledge of conquest:  while in vain,</br>To guard your altars, your paternal lands,</br>Are social arms held out to your free hands:</br>Too arduous is the lore; too irksome were the pain.

Meantime by pleasure's sophistry allur'd,</br>From the bright sun and living breeze ye stray;</br>And deep in London's gloomy haunts immur'd,</br>Brood o'er your fortune's, freedom's, health's decay.</br>O blind of choice and to yourselves untrue!</br>The young grove shoots, their bloom the fields renew,</br>The mansion asks its lord, the swains their friend;</br>While he doth riot's orgies haply share,</br>Or tempt the gamester's dark, destroying snare,</br>Or at some courtly shrine with slavish incense bend.

And yet full oft your anxious tongues complain</br>That lawless tumult prompts the rustic throng;</br>That the rude village-inmates now disdain</br>Those homely ties which rul'd their fathers long.</br>Alas, your fathers did by other arts</br>Draw those kind ties around their simple hearts,</br>And led in other paths their ductile will;</br>By succour, faithful counsel, courteous cheer,</br>Won them the ancient manners to revere,</br>To prize their country's peace and heaven's due rites fulfill.

But mark the judgement of experienc'd Time,</br>Tutor of nations.  Doth light discord tear</br>A state?  and impotent sedition's crime?</br>The pow'rs of warlike prudence dwell not there;</br>The pow'rs who to command and to obey,</br>Instruct the valiant.  There would civil sway</br>The rising race to manly concord tame?</br>Oft let the marshall'd field their steps unite,</br>And in glad splendor bring before their sight</br>One common cause and one hereditary fame.

Nor yet be aw'd, nor yet your task disown,</br>Though war's proud votaries look on severe;</br>Though secrets, taught erewhile to them alone,</br>They deem profan'd by your intruding ear.</br>Let them in vain, your martial hope to quell,</br>Of new refinements, fiercer weapons tell,</br>And mock the old simplicity, in vain:</br>To the time's warfare, simple or refin'd,</br>The time itself adapts the warrior's mind;</br>And equal prowess still shall equal palms obtain.

Say then; if England's youth, in earlier days,</br>On glory's field with well-train'd armies vy'd,</br>Why shall they now renounce that generous praise?</br>Why dread the foreign mercenary's pride?</br>Though Valois brav'd young Edward's gentle hand,</br>And D'Albret rush'd on Henry's way-worn band,</br>With Europe's chosen sons in arms renown'd,</br>Yet not on Vere's bold archers long they look'd,</br>Nor Audley's squires nor Mowbray's yeomen brook'd:</br>They saw their standard fall, and left their monarch bound.

Such were the laurels which your fathers won;</br>Such glory's dictates in their dauntless breast:</br>—Is there no voice that speaks to every son?</br>No nobler, holier call to You address'd?</br>O!  by majestic freedom, righteous laws,</br>By heav'nly truth's, by manly reason's cause,</br>Awake; attend; be indolent no more:</br>By friendship, social peace, domestic love,</br>Rise; arm; your country's living safety prove;</br>And train her valiant youth, and watch around her shore.</br>
